questions.text: The most common banding technique used for the staining of chromosomes in Karyotyping is
questions.solution:
• G banding (Giemsa banding) is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype by staining condensed chromosomes.
  • It is useful for identifying genetic diseases through the photographic representation of the entire chromosome complement.
  • The metaphase chromosomes are treated with trypsin (to partially digest the chromosome) and stained with Giemsa stain.
  • Heterochromatic regions, which tend to be rich with adenine and thymine (AT-rich) DNA and relatively gene-poor, stain more darkly and appear as Dark bands in G-banding.
  • In contrast, less condensed chromatin—which tends to be rich with guanine and cytosine (GC-rich) and more transcriptionally active—incorporates less Giemsa stain, and these regions appear as light bands in G-banding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common karyotype among the sex chromosomal disorders in phenotypic females ?
questions.solution:
• Turner's syndrome is the most common sex chromosomal disorder in phenotypic females.
  • The most frequent chromosome constitution in Turner syndrome is 45,X (sometimes written incorrectly as 45,XO), with no second sex chromosome.
  • Typical abnormalities in Turner syndrome include short stature, gonadal dysgenesis (usually streak gonads reflecting a failure of ovarian maintenance), characteristic unusual facies, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and elevated frequency of renal and cardiovascular anomalies.
  • At birth, infants with this syndrome often have edema of the dorsum of the foot, a useful diagnostic sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cutaneous malignant tumor?
questions.solution:
• Basal Cell Carcinoma(BCC) is the most common skin cancer, than all other skin cancers combined.
  • Amongst the non melanoma cancers group BCC constitutes 74% whereas SCC constitutes 23% only.
  • Melanoma constitutes only 4% of skin cancers but causes 80% of skin cancer related deaths.

questions.text: Which of the following types is the most common presentation of psoriatic arthritis?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of Psoriatic arthritis.

Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints in the fingers or toes, often with dactylitis.

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative inflammatory arthritis that is destructive to the joints, associated with moderate to severe psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age.

A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

  1. Current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis
  2. Typical psoriatic nail involvement
  3. Rheumatoid factor negative
  4. Current or history of dactylitis
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Triggers include trauma to a joint or tendon (Koebner effect), smoking, alcohol excess and HIV infection. Streptococcal infection, medications like lithium or stress do not trigger the onset of psoriatic arthritis. There is an activation of both innate and acquired immunity with the overproduction of cytokines like TNF‐α, IL‐17 and IL‐23 via the JAK-STAT pathway. This results in joint fibrosis and erosion of bone with abnormal bone formation.

Wright & Moll Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Arthritis of the DIP joints
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis
  • Symmetric polyarthritis
  • Axial involvement such as spine and sacroiliac joints
  • Arthritis mutilans, a destructive form of arthritis

Psoriatic arthritis involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). Clinical features include:

  • Early morning stiffness
  • Swollen, tender, one or more joints
  • Enthesitis: Heel pain due to Achilles tendon inflammation
  • Plantar fasciitis
  • Dactylitis /sausage fingers with telescoping (shortening of toes due to osteolysis)
  • Nail changes: hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
  • Axial involvement may occur

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:

 

Investigations include:

  • Inflammatory markers like CRP, ESR
  • Tests to rule out other arthritis: uric acid, rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibodies
  • Plain X‐rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease, which show:
    • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
    • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'
  • MRI to assess axial disease and enthesitis

Given below is an X-ray showing the 'pencil-in-cup' appearance of the metacarpophalangeal joints

Psoriatic arthritis should be managed by a rheumatologist. Early treatment and interventions are necessary to prevent irreversible joint damage. The Group for Research and Assessment of Psoriasis and Psoriatic Arthritis (GRAPPA) management guidelines for psoriatic arthritis states the use of the following drugs in:

  • Peripheral arthritis: NSAIDs/ steroid injection/ Systemic treatments - methotrexate, cyclosporin/ biologicals
  • Dactylitis: NSAIDs/ Steroid injection
  • Axial disease / Enthesitis: NSAIDs / Physiotherapy / Biologicals

Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis, and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Newer drugs approved for the treatment of Psoriatic arthritis include:

Class of drug Drugs
Anti-TNF α

- Infliximab (only iv drug, rest all are s/c)
- Etanercept 
- Adalimumab 
- Golimumab
- Certolizumab
Anti-IL-17 - Secukinumab 
Anti-IL-23 - Ustekinumab 

Psoriatic arthritis is found to be associated with ocular diseases like conjunctivitis, uveitis, iridocyclitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca and cataracts, obesity/metabolic syndrome, alcohol misuse and premature cardiovascular disease.

Differential diagnoses include:

  • Early rheumatoid arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Gout
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Fibromyalgia

Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis. Previously, symmetric polyarthritis was marked as the correct answer (based on Harrison's Textbook of Internal Medicine 20th Edition). However, after thorough review of literature and consultation of expert faculty, the answer has been changed to asymetric oligoarthritis as per:

  • Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition - (Page no 35.44) 
  • ABC of Rheumatology 2018, Wiley-Blackwell- British Medical Journal (Page No 85)
  • Kelley and Firestein's Textbook of Rheumatology, 10th Edition (Page No 1288)

questions.text: The  most common causative organism of pyomyositis is:
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing Pyomyositis.

Pyomyositis also known as tropical pyomyositis or myositis tropicans is a bacterial infection of skeletal muscles resulting in pus filled abscess that is seen primarily in tropical climates but also occurs in immunocompromised and HIV-infected patients.

Causative Organism:

  • Tropical pyomyositis – Most Common cause is S. Aureus
  • Acute bacterial myositis – Most Common cause is Group A Streptococcus
  • Overall - Most Common cause of pyomyositis is S.aureus

Clinical Presentation:

  • Children aged 2 – 5 years are most commonly affected.
  • Pyomyositis presents as fever, swelling, and pain overlying the involved muscle.
  • Most common Muscles infected by pyomyositis are Quadriceps and Gluteal Muscles.

Treatment:

  • Surgical drainage of abscess followed by antibiotics for minimum three weeks to treat infection.

questions.text: A 25 year old man with 3 weeks fever presented with tricuspid valve vegetation. Patient is intravenous drug abuser. Most common cause of endocarditis in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of endocarditis in Intravenous drug users.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

 Condition

Most common organism

Most common organism overall

Staphylococcus aureus

Community-acquired native valve endocarditis

Streptococci

Healthcare-associated native valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Right side) Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Left side) Enterococci and Staphylococcus aureus

Single most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Most common group of organism causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery)

 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)*

Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (>12 months after surgery)

Streptococci

 

Acute infective endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Subacute infective endocarditis

Streptococcus viridans

Enterococci

Coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)

HACEK

Cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)-associated endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus  and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)*

Culture negative endocarditis

Prior antibiotic use

Nutritionally variant streptococci

HACEK organisms

Coxiella burnetii

Bartonella

NOTE :

*CoNS includes Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative types

*Streptococci includes Viridans streptococci (VGS), Streptococcus gallolyticus (previously Streptococcus bovis biotype 1) and other non-groupable and groupable streptococci

 

Microorganism

Source

Streptococcus viridans

Oral cavity

Staphylococcus aureus

Skin

HACEK organisms

Upper respiratory tract

Streptococcus gallolyticus

GIT (Colon )

Enterococci

Genitourinary tract

questions.text: The most common cause of Portal hypertention is:
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of portal hypertension is cirrhosis of the liver followed by portal vein obstruction.
  • Portal hypertension is defined as portal pressure > 10mmHg or 30 cm saline.
  • The normal pressure in portal vein is 2-5 mmHg or 10-15 cm saline.
  • PHT is present is 70% cases of cirrhosis of liver.
  • Cirrhosis is present in 90% cases of PHT.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: The most common cause of swelling of the Eyelids is
questions.solution:
• Meibomian cyst is the most common cause of swelling of Eyelids.
  • Meibomian cyst (Chalazion) is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of a meibomian gland.
  • It may occur on either upper or lower lids and presents as a smooth, painless swelling.
  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the eyelids.
  • Other less common causes of lid swelling include sebaceous cysts, papillomas, keratoacanthomas, cysts of Moll (sweat glands)  or Zeis (sebaceous glands) and molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common neoplasm of Kidney?

choices.text: Papillary transitional cell tumours of the renal pelvis
Squamous cell carcinoma of the renal pelvis
Transitional cell tumours of the ureter

questions.solution:
• Hypernephroma, an Adenocarcinoma (also known as Grawitz’s tumour)  is the most common neoplasm of the kidney (75% incidence), arises from renal tubular cells.
  • Adenocarcinoma of the kidney is twice as common in men as in women.
  • Haematuria is usually the presenting symptom, sometimes with clot colic.
  • Investigations include Intravenous urography for detecting Hematuria, Plain X-Ray and Contrast enhanced CT.
  • Treatment: If the tumour is confined to the kidney, treatment is nephrectomy with removal of the perinephric fat.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of Atrial Septal defect?
questions.solution:
• The most common type of Atrial septal defect is Ostium secundum type.
  • Approximately 70% of all Atrial septal defects are Ostium secundum type.
  • Ostium secundum is caused by a defect in the floor of the fossa ovalis, resulting in failure of the septum secundum to develop completely and cover the foramen ovale.

questions.text: Most common route of nosocomial infections:
questions.solution:
• Most common route of nosocomial infections are through direct contact.
  • Indirect contact refers to contact with infectious objects.
  • Vehicle transmission and droplet transmission are also routes of nosocomial infections.
  • Nosocomial infections are hospital acquired infections like blood stream infections and surgical site infections.

questions.text: Most common site of hospital acquired infections:
questions.solution:
• Urinary tract infections are the most common hospital acquired or nosocomial infections.
  • Respiratory tract infections and blood stream infections are also common nosocomial infections.

questions.text: Most common occupational cancer is:
questions.solution:
• Nearly 75% of all cancer related to occupational health are skin cancers.
  • Skin cancers are occupational hazards among gas workers, tar distillers, dye makers and those who work with radioactive materials.
  • Other cancers like bladder cancer and leukemia are occupational hazards in certain industries.

questions.text: Most common cause of failure of male sterilization is:

choices.text: Advanced age at the time of procedure

questions.solution:
Most common cause of failure of male sterilization or vasectomy is mistake in identifying the vas.

Although the failure rate of vasectomy is low, sometimes failure arises as some other structure in the spermatic cord is taken.

Histological confirmation or microscopy with staining is recommended in vasectomy procedures.

questions.text: Most common cause of maternal mortality in India is:
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of maternal deaths in India is hemorrhage.
  • Other common causes are hypertension, sepsis, anesthetic complications during obstetric surgery and abortion.
  • The MMR of India declined to 130 per 100,000 live births in the 2014 – 2016 period.

questions.text: Most common complication in IUCD responsible for its removal
questions.solution:
• Pain accounts for 15-40% of IUD removal, hence it is the most common cause of IUD removal.
  • However, bleeding is the most common side-effect reported after IUD insertion.
  • Disturbances in menstrual bleeding are very commonly reported in the forms of increased blood loss or irregular bleeding.
  • Studies have shown that larger non-medicated IUDs cause greater incidences of bleeding than copper devices and hormone-releasing devices.
  • Other side-effects and complications are pain, pelvic infection, uterine perforation and ectopic pregnancies.

questions.text: Most common mode of occupational lead poisoning is:
questions.solution:
• Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead is the most common mode of occupational lead poisoning.
  • Ingestion and absorption through skin are other modes of occupational lead poisoning in industries.

questions.text: Most common cause of infant mortality in India is:
questions.solution:
• Close to 60% of infant deaths in India is due to low birth weight.
  • Other causes of infant deaths are respiratory infections, diarrheal disease, congenital anomalies, cord infections and other unclassified causes.

questions.text: Most common route of transmission of HIV in India is:
questions.solution:
• In India, the transmission is predominantly heterosexual which accounts for more than 80% of cases.
  • Other routes of transmission in India are homosexual transmission, parent-to-child, intravenous drug usage and blood products.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly used measure of dispersion?
questions.solution:
• Standard deviation is the most commonly used measure of dispersion as it measures the average distance of each score from the mean.
  • It is denoted by the Greek letter sigma or just by SD.
  • Other measures of dispersion are mean deviation and range.

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in India is:
questions.solution:
• Cataract is the most common cause of blindness in India accounting for more than 60% of cases of blindness.
  • Other leading causes of blindness in India are refractive errors and glaucoma.

questions.text: Most common cause of brucellosis worldwide is:
questions.solution:
• Brucella melitensis is the most prevalent worldwide and causes infections with the most virulence and severity.
  • Main reservoirs of Brucella are cattle, sheep, goats, buffaloes and dogs.

questions.text: Most common study used for developing etiological hypothesis:
questions.solution:
• Descriptive studies are most commonly used to develop an etiological hypothesis.
  • Diseases are described by their distribution in terms of time, place and person in these studies.

questions.text: Vitiligo is most commonly associated with which of the following autoimmune disorders?
questions.solution:
Amongst autoimmune diseases, the strongest association of vitiligo is with thyroid disease.

One of the theories for the etiology of vitiligo is based on the clinical association of vitiligo with a number of autoimmune disorders like -

  • Thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism)
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Alopecia areata

Vitiligo is a localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes in the basal layer of skin. It is classified as

  • Segmental vitiligo- which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern
  • Non-segmental vitiligo- which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body. Non-segmental can either be focal vitiligo or undetermined/unclassified vitiligo.

According to a recent Vitiligo Global Issue Consensus Conference, the term ‘vitiligo’ can be used as an umbrella term for all non‐segmental forms of vitiligo (including several variants: acrofacial, mucosal, generalized, universal, mixed, and rare variants of vitiligo). The classification is shown below


Vitiligo (Non segmental)
  • Acrofacial
  • Mucosal (>1 one mucosal site)
  • Generalized
  • Universal
  • Mixed (associated with SV)
  • Rare variants
Segmental vitiligo
  • Uni-, bi-, or pleuri-segmental

Undetermined/

unclassified vitiligo
  • Focal
  • Mucosal (one site in isolation)

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Koebner phenomenon is seen, which is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Vitiligo universalis, which is complete vitiligo, or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, hyperpigmentation, as well as areas of normal skin may be seen rarely.

Under the Wood's lamp examination the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated. 

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and the use of sunscreen. The topical application of corticosteroids is the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus have also shown to be successful. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin and selective ultraviolet B therapy are used as second-line treatment. In patients who do not respond to this treatment, surgical grafting techniques can be used, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non pigmented area. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Poor prognostic factors for vitiligo:

  • Positive family history 
  • Mucosal vitiligo 
  • Lesions over bony prominences
  • Isomorphic Koebner's phenomenon 
  • Non-segmental vitiligo

Leucotrichia, longer duration, and higher age at onset do not correlate significantly with progression.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

Related Pearl: Algorithm for the differential diagnosis of Hypomelanosis

questions.text: A farmer presents with eczematous eruption all over his upper limbs and face. He has had similar episodes during previous cultivation times also and you suspect airborne contact dermatitis. Which of the following would have commonly caused this?
questions.solution:
In India, the weed Parthenium is the most common cause of airborne contact dermatitis.

Many allergenic plants, especially those belonging to the Compositae (Asteraceae) family, are destroyed by cold and frosty weather, but return during the warmer spring and summer months. Compositae allergy is seen in many parts of the world, but the plants responsible vary.

  • Ragweed is the main cause in the USA (Option D)
  • Chrysanthemums and garden weeds in Europe
  • Toxicodendron species are mainly seen in North America

After confirming the allergen using patch test, avoidance of contact and topical corticosteroids is the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: Most common cause of irritant contact dermatitis in indian females is
questions.solution:
Detergents are the most common cause of irritant contact dermatitis in Indian women.

  • Detergents at lower levels of exposure predominantly affect the horny layer, causing dryness and scaling by destroying lysosomal enzymes in the horny layer.
  • At higher concentrations, they will dissolve cell membranes and damage lysosomes.
  • With repeated exposure, there will be signs of chronic inflammation, acanthosis, and changes in cellular metabolism.

Irritant contact dermatitis is a cutaneous response to the physical/toxic effects of a wide range of environmental exposures. It is not an immunologically mediated reaction.

It is also called wear and tear dermatitis. Examples include housewives' eczema due to soaps and detergents and wetwork, napkin, or diaper rash. 

Treatment includes avoidance of irritants, personal protection, and 'barrier creams'.

Irritant contact dermatitis Allergic contact dermatitis
Not an immunologically mediated reaction Immunologically mediated reaction (type-IV delayed hypersensitivity)
It can occur in anyone without predisposing factors It only occurs in those individuals with a history of atopy
Sensitization is not required  Sensitization phase required
Predominantly burning sensation Predominantly itching sensation

questions.text: A 50-year old patient presented with scaly plaques, well-demarcated from unaffected skin, with sharply delineated edges as shown in the image given below. The lesions showed an isomorphic response and the Auspitz sign was positive. Which of the following types is the most common variant of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriasis, with the image showing well-demarcated scaly plaques surrounded by Woronoff's rings. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis.

Plaque/Discoid psoriasis, also known as psoriasis vulgaris accounts for almost 90% of all psoriasis cases. It presents as a papulosquamous rash, with reddish edematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, which are well-demarcated from unaffected skin with sharply delineated edges. Plaques may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the halo or ring of Woronoff. The scalp is one of the most common and first affected areas in plaque psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash

It is linked to infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which cause proliferation of keratinocytes. This leads to the formation of thick plaques, epidermal hyperplasia, and parakeratosis. 

It can occur in sites of cutaneous trauma and old scarring, termed as Koebner's phenomenon. It is suggested that trauma stimulates immune activation. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients.

The image below shows Koebner's phenomenon seen in plaque psoriasis.

Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  1. Beta-blockers
  2. Synthetic antimalarials
  3. NSAIDS
  4. Lithium
  5. ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  6. Interferon alpha
  7. Tetracycline
  8. Terbinafine
  9. Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

Lesions can be described as:

  • Red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • Encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • Appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

  • Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.)
  • Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities
  • Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized and exanthemic variants are described
  • Scalp psoriasis: well demarcated plaques on the retroauricular areas and posterior upper neck
  • Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent
  • Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns
  • Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches and leukonychia are common on the nail plate

  • Signs:

    • Koebner phenomenon: new psoriatic papules at sites of skin trauma
    • Auspitz sign: pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed

Woronoff ring: an area of blanching surrounding resolving psoriatic plaques

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: The most common cause of Erythema multiforme
questions.solution:
The most common triggering factor of Erythema multiforme is with a preceding herpes simplex infection (facial or genital).

Erythema multiforme is best regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

It presents clinically with a spectrum of macular, papular or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic acral iris or ‘target lesions’ .

questions.text: The most effective drug against M.leprae is
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the only drug that is highly bactericidal against M.leprae.

A single dose of 1500 mg or 3-4 consecutive daily doses of 600mg appears to kill 99% of viable organism.

The drug is effective when given at monthly intervals which is a big advantage. The drug is expensive but safe.

When given alone, resistance develops. Hence it is given in combination with other anti-leprosy drugs.

Other options:

Option a: Dapsone

  • It is a weak bactericidal against M. leprae
  • It is cheap and effective
  • When given orally, it is completely absorbed from the gut and well tolerated

Option c: Clofazimine

  • It is less effective than Dapsone, but suppresses and prevents reactions.
  • Anti-leprosy and anti-inflammatory properties.
  • Relatively expensive.
  • Used as a third drug in leprosy chemotherapy.

Option d: Prothionamide

  • Bactericidal drug that can kills 98% viable organism in 4-5 days
  • Interchangeable with and has cross resistance with ethionamide
  • More expensive and toxic than dapsone
  • Used as a third drug in leprosy chemotherapy

questions.text: Most common type of cutaneous TB is
questions.solution:
• Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis in adults in published series from India, South Africa and Pakistan.
  • This is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary form of cutaneous tuberculosis, occurring in a previously sensitized individual with a high degree of immunity to tuberculin.
  • The characteristic lesion is a plaque, composed of soft, reddish brown papules, the appearance on diascopy being said to resemble apple jelly.
  • The above image is of the diascopic examination.
  • The lesion is pressed by a glass slide to diminish the vascular component of inflammation showing yellow-brown colored nodules also known as apple jelly nodules.

questions.text: Most common nerve used during monitoring of anesthesia
questions.solution:
• In anaesthetic practice, neuromuscular block is monitored by recording the contractile responses of thumb muscle (adductor pollicis) to transcutaneous ulnar nerve stimulation.
  • Facial nerve stimulation of orbicularis oculi is the second most common.

questions.text: The most common mass in the middle mediastinum is
questions.solution:
• Most common anterior mediastinal mass: thymoma
  • Most common middle mediastinal mass in adults: Cysts
  • Most common posterior mediastinal mass: neurogenic tumours

In children,

  • Most common posterior mediastinal mass: neurogenic tumours
  • Most common mediastinal mass in anterior/middle mediastinum: lymphoma

questions.text: Most common hallucination seen with organic disease states
questions.solution:
• Most common hallucination seen with organic disease states – visual hallucination.
  • Most common hallucination seen in non-organic psychiatric illness in the auditory hallucination.

Types:

  • Auditory: Most common type of hallucination. 3rd person hallucination is characteristic of schizophrenia. Auditory hallucinations are also seen in alcoholic hallucinosis, pontine or temporal lobe lesions.
  • Visual: Seen in patients with organic brain lesions: delirium, occipital tumors, epilepsy, substance abuse: Intoxication of LSD and amphetamines, alcohol both in intoxication and withdrawal) and dementia.
  • Unformed visual hallucination: occipital lobe or ocular disease.
  • Formed visual hallucination: temporal lobe lesions, schizophrenia.
  • Olfactory and Gustatory: Temporal lobe diseases (Ex: complex partial seizure), Depression and schizophrenia.
  • Tactile: Schizophrenia and formication: cocaine, alcohol withdrawal.
  • Somatic hallucination: Hallucination involving the perception of physical appearance localised within the body.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of delusion?
questions.solution:
• Delusion of persecution is the most common type of delusion.
  • Delusion: False, fixed belief which is held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof or evidence and despite the fact that other members of the culture do not share the belief.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Most common dissociative disorder is?
questions.solution:
• Commonest dissociative disorder- dissociative amnesia
  • Commonest symptom of hysterical state- motor/ sensory
  • Other Causes of fugue (besides dissociative disorder) - Alzheimer’s disease, temporal lobe epilepsy, schizophrenia

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common eating disorder ?
questions.solution:
• The 12-month prevalence of anorexia nervosa among young females is approximately 0.4%. Less is known about prevalence among males, but it is far less common in males than in females, with a 10:1 female-to-male ratio
  • The 12-month prevalence of bulimia nervosa among young females is 1%-1.5% (10:1 female-to-male ratio)
  • The 12-month prevalence of binge-eating disorder among U.S. adult (age 18 or older) females and males is 1.6% and 0.8%, respectively. 

From these statistics, it is clear that binge eating disorder is the most common eating disorder.

EATING DISORDERS
Anorexia Nervosa
CLINICAL FEATURES Treatment

Intense fear of weight gain

Significantly low body weight

Distorted views of body weight and shape

Mild (BMI >or =17), Moderate(16-16.99), Severe (15-15.99) and Extreme (< 15)

Cognitive Behavioural therapy

Nutritional rehabilitation Olanzapine if no response to above
Bulimia Nervosa

Recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behavior to prevent weight gain

Excessive worry about body  weight and shape Maintains Normal BMI (18.5-30)

Cognitive-behavioral therapy

Nutritional rehabilitation

SSRI (fluoxetine) in combination with above
Binge eating disorder

Recurrent episodes of binge-eating

No compensatory behavior Lack of control during eating

 Cognitive behavioral therapy Behavioural weight loss therapy SSRI, Lisdexamfetamine, topiramate

questions.text: Which the following is the most common side effect of antipsychotics?
questions.solution:
Acute Akathisia is the most common side effect of antipsychotic drugs.

Types of movement disorders associated with anti-psychotic drugs:

Acute Dystonia (Dystonic Reaction)

  • Can occur within hours after treatment
  • Presentation: Spasms of various muscle groups
  • Can be dramatic and frightening to patient
  • Can be a major contributing factor to subsequent noncompliance with treatment
  • Young men may be at higher risk, seen in 10% patients.
  • Treatment: anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl

Akathisia

  • Can occur several weeks after treatment 
  • Presenting Symptoms: Motor restlessness, “ants in your pants”
  • Differential Diagnosis: Often mistaken for anxiety and agitation
  • Treatment: lowering the dose, adding benzodiazepines or beta-blockers, switching to other antipsychotic medication

Tardive Dyskinesia (TD)

  • Can occur after 3–6 months after treatment
  • Characterized by choreoathetosis and other involuntary movements
  • Movements often occur first in the tongue or fingers and later involve the trunk
  • Etiology may be a form of “chemical denervation hypersensitivity,” which is caused by chronic dopamine blockade in the basal ganglia.
  • Patients who take high doses of older antipsychotic medication for long periods of time are at highest risk, and movements gradually worsen with continued use.
  • Treatment: Use newer antipsychotic medications.
  • Seen more frequently in elderly females

 

Other side effects: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome, Drug induced Parkinsonism, QT prolongation (atypical antipsychotics especially ziprasidone).

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions
Time of onset
Features
Treatment
Acute dystonia
1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine
Akathisia
5 to 60 days
Restlessness
Propranolol, lorazepam, diphenhydramine, benztropine
Parkinsonism
5 to 30 days
Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors
Dose reduction, change medication, antiparkinsonian agents
Tardive dyskinesia
Months to years
Orofacial dyskinesia (may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation)
VMAT-2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Weeks to months
Extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure
Dantrolene

questions.text: Most common cause of dementia is
questions.solution:
Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia.

Alzheimer’s disease:

Age of onset>60 years, MMSE <24

Diagnosis: clinical

2 or more areas of cognitive deficits

Progressive worsening of memory

and other cognitive function

No disturbance in consciousness    

Other systemic causes must be ruled out

Risk factors:

Most important: old age

Genetic factors – positive family

history, presenilin -1, presenilin – 2,

Apolipoprotein E 4, Ubiquitin, and

Down syndrome.

Protective factors: NSAIDs,

Smoking,

Apolipoprotein E2 

Early findings: Anterograde memory loss (immediate

recall affected, distant memories preserved)

Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighbourhood)

Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)

Cognitive impairment with progressive decline

Late findings:Psych symptoms: hallucination

Dyspraxia: difficulty to perform

learned motor tasks

Lack of insight regarding deficits

Non cognitive neurologic deficits:

pyramidal and extrapyramidal,

myoclonus and seizures

Urinary incontinence

Histopathology: Senile plaques

(amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary

tangles, neuronal loss, synaptic loss,

and granulo-vacuolar degeneration of neurons.

CT/MRI: later stages: cortical and

subcortical atrophy prominent in

parietal and temporal lobes,

particularly hippocampus.

Treatment:Cholinesterase inhibitors: Donepezil,

Galantamine, Rivastigmine.

NMDA antagonist: Memantine
                                    Differential diagnosis of Dementia  
Alzheimer disease (most common) Early, insidious onset short-term memory loss. Language deficits and spatial disorientationLater personality changes
Vascular dementia

Stepwise decline

Early executive dysfunction Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia (pick’s disease)

Early personality changes

Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviour Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Lewy body dementia Visual hallucination Spontaneous parkinsonism Fluctuating cognition
Normal pressure hydrocephalus Ataxia early in disease Urinary incontinence Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging.
Prion disease Behavioural changes Rapidly progressive Myoclonus &/or seizures

questions.text: Most common psychiatric disorder is?
questions.solution:
Depression is the most common psychiatric disorder.

It affects around 15% of the population. It is most common in middle-aged females.

questions.text: Most common substance abused in India
questions.solution:
According to National mental health survey of India, alcohol is the second most substance abused in India.

The most common substance abused is tobacco.

Out of the given options, alcohol is the best answer.

questions.text: Most common radiation used in radiotherapy is?
questions.solution:
• LINAC (Linear accelerator) machines are currently most commonly used for Radiation therapy.
  • Principle of linear accelerators are used in production of X-rays.
  • Hence X-rays are most common radiation used in radiotherapy. If X-rays is not there in the option, second best answer would be gamma rays.

questions.text: Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for external beam radiotherapy in treatment of cancer patients?
questions.solution:
• Cobalt-60 isotope is used for EBRT.
  • Cobalt and LINAC (Linear accelerator) machines are used for giving external beam radiotherapy.
  • In Cobalt machine Co 60 isotope is used.
  • They emit radiation of energy 1.25 Mev. Gamma rays produced by cobalt machine is used for radiotherapy.
  • LINAC (Linear accelerator) machine’s cancer therapy is based on X-ray generation and not based on isotope.
  • Continuous spectrum of different energy radiations are produced that is orthovoltage, supervoltage and megavoltage.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most radiosensitive?
questions.solution:
• Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are among the most radiosensitive cells in the body.
  • Heavily irradiated bone marrow (>30 Gy) may never fully recover. This may be seen as abnormal marrow signal on MRI persisting for many years.

questions.text: Element most commonly used in brachytherapy of carcinoma cervix:
questions.solution:
• Caesium is the most commonly radioactive agent for brachytherapy in carcinoma cervix.
  • Brachytherapy refers to radiation that is given from a short distance, in contrast to external beam radiation, or tele therapy, which is given from a longer distance.
  • In the majority of these treatments radiation applicators are placed within a cavity of the body such as the bronchus (airway) in the lung, esophagus, vagina, cervix of uterus.
  • The primary advantage of internal radiation is the ability to deliver a higher radiation dose while the normal tissues receive less radiation since the radiation sources are placed within the tumor.
  • Both iridium and caesium have been used as radioactive sources to give the internal radiation.

questions.text: The most common complication of loop diuretic
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is the most common complication of loop diuretics.

  • Degree of Hypokalemia depends on the duration of action of the drug – longer acting drugs have higher risk.
  • Presents with - weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps; cardiac arrhythmias are the serious complications.
  • Hypokalaemia can be prevented and treated by:
    • High dietary K+ intake
    • Supplements of KCl (24–72 mEq/day)
    • Concurrent use of K+ sparing diuretics

questions.text: Most common site for ectopic gestation
questions.solution: Ampulla of the fallopian tube (55%) is the most common site of ectopic gestation.

questions.text: The most common cause of posterior staphyloma
questions.solution:
• Degenerative high axial myopia is the most common cause of posterior staphyloma.
  • Staphyloma refers to ectasia of outer coats of the eyeball (cornea or sclera or both) with the incarceration of uveal tissue.
  • Posterior staphyloma affects posterior pole of eyes and is lined by choroid.
  • Most common cause – degenerative high axial myopia.
  • Investigations :
    • Fundoscopy, B scan ultrasonography.
    • Indirect ophthalmoscopy – Crescentic shadow in the macular region (due to posterior outward curvature of glove).
  • Treatment:
    • Treat underlying cause.
    • Local excision and repair with corneal or sclera patch.
    • Staphylectomy and keratoplasty or enucleation and replacement with implant – for large, unsightly blind eyes.

The most common cause of anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.

questions.text: Most common arrhythmia seen during laparoscopy is
questions.solution:
• Most common arrhythmia created by laparoscopy is bradycardia.
  • Cause - A rapid stretch of the peritoneal membrane often causes a vagovagal response with bradycardia and occasionally hypotension.
  • Treatment:
    • Desufflation of the abdomen
    • Administration of vagolytic agents (e.g., atropine)
    • Adequate volume replacement

questions.text: Most common cause of early cyanosis in a baby is
questions.solution:
• VSD is most common cause of congenital heart disease but causes late cyanosis.
  • Transposition of the great vessels, a common cyanotic congenital anomaly, accounts for ≈5% of all congenital heart disease.Cyanosis and tachypnea are most often recognized within the 1st hr or days of life.
  • In TOF often, cyanosis is not present at birth; but with increasing hypertrophy of the right ventricular infundibulum as the patient
    grows, cyanosis occurs later in the 1st yr of life.
  • Hence, TGV is considered to be the most common cause of early cyanosis in an infant.

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases:

Cardiac right-to-left shunt

  • Abnormal connections (pulmonary blood flow normal or increased)
    • Transposition of great vessels
    • Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
    • Truncus arteriosus
    • Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
    • Single ventricle or tricuspid atresia with large ventricular septal defect but without pulmonic stenosis
  • Obstructed pulmonary blood flow (pulmonary blood flow decreased)
    • Pulmonic atresia with intact ventricular septum
    • Tetralogy of fallot
    • Critical pulmonic stenosis with patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect
    • Tricuspid atresia
    • Single ventricle with pulmonic stenosis
    • Ebstein malformation of the tricuspid valve
    • Persistent fetal circulation (persistent pulmonary hypertension of newborn)

questions.text: Most common serotype of HPV associated with invasive cervical carcinoma is?
questions.solution:
• HPV is associated with 80% of CIN and over 90% of invasive carcinoma.
  • HPV -16 is most common HPV associated with squamous cell carcinoma.
  • HPV -18 is most common HPV associated with Adenocarcinoma.
  • Histologically 95% of cervical carcinoma are SCC and only 5% adenocarcinoma.
  • Hence HPV 16 is the most common serotype of HPV associated with cervical carcinoma.

On the basis of strength of association to Ca cervix, HPV has been classified into:

  • Low risk type-6, 11, 42, 43
    • Causes CIN and condyloma acuminata.
  • Intermediate risk-33, 35, 55, 52
    • Causes CIN I and CIN that don't progress.
  • High risk- 16, 18,31,39,45,56,48, 59
    • Causes high grade CIN that progresses to invasive ca.

questions.text: Most common site of ischemic colitis is
questions.solution: Splenic flexure is supplied by end arteries from superior and inferior mesenteric artery -> watershed zone -> prone to ischemia secondary to decreased supply esp. hypotension.

questions.text: Most common cause of meningitis in immunocompromised patients is
questions.solution: Although hosts with cell-mediated immune deficiency (including transplant recipients, diabetic patients, elderly patients, and cancer patients receiving certain chemotherapeutic agents) are at particular risk for Listeria monocytogenes meningitis, most cases in adults are due to S. pneumoniae (30–60%) and N. meningitidis (10–35%).

questions.text: Most common malignancy developing after head and neck radiation in childhood :
questions.solution: The single most important etiological factor in differentiated thyroid carcinoma, particularly papillary, is irradiation of the thyroid under five years of age.

questions.text: Most common cranial nerve involved in sarcoidosis:
questions.solution:
• The most common cranial nerve involved in Sarcoidosis is the seventh nerve, which can be affected bilaterally.
  • Nerve biopsy can reveal noncaseating granulomas infiltrating the endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium along with lymphocytic necrotizing angiitis.
  • Neurosarcoidosis may respond to treatment with glucocorticoids or other immunosuppressive agents.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Pain is the most common symptom of chronic pancreatitis.

Pain in chronic pancreatitis is usually, mid-epigastric in location but may localize or involve either the left or right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Often described as radiating through to the back or shoulder. Typically steady and boring, but not colicky. 

Patients with chronic pancreatic pain typically flex their abdomen and either sit or lie with their hips flexed, or lie on their side in a fetal position.

The part of the pancreas that is affected largely determines the site of pain: 

  • Head of the pancreas - epigastric and right subcostal
  • Tail of pancreas - left subcostal and back 

Other symptoms include:

  • Nausea and vomiting. 
  • Exocrine insufficiency symptoms
  • endocrine insufficiency symptoms

Burned-out pancreatitis –

  • The pain of chronic pancreatitis may decrease or disappear completely over a period of years, as symptoms of exocrine and endocrine deficiency become apparent.
  • It indicates progression to a more severe stage.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

questions.text: Most common complication after splenectomy is
questions.solution: Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after OS; pleural effusion and pneumonia also can occur.

questions.text: Retinal tears are most commonly seen in
questions.solution:
• Retinal tears are more common in upper temporal retina.
  • Retinal breaks are most frequently found in the periphery - commonest in the upper temporal quadrant.
  • Retinal tears are usually  horseshoe- or arrow shaped with a lid-like tongue pulled inwards by the vitreous
  • Those involving more than a quadrant of the circumference are called giant retinal tears.

questions.text: Most common cause of short limbed dwarfism is?
questions.solution:
Most common cause of short limbed dwarfism is achondroplasia.

Achondroplasia:

  • The most common form of short-limbed dwarfism,  achondroplasia, is caused by mutations in the gene for a receptor for a fibroblastic growth factor (FGFR3).
  • It is a form of autosomal dominant disorder.
  • Affected individuals have short limbs, normal trunk size, macrocephaly with midfacial hypoplasia and prominent forehead.
  • Thoracolumbar gibbus is another distinct feature seen.
  • Diagnosis can be done by prenatal ultrasound and DNA testing.

questions.text: Most common primary orbital tumour in children is:
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common primary orbital tumour among children, usually occurring below the age of 15 years (90%), slightly more common in males.

Ocular tumor most common list (mc)

  • MC cause of eyelid tumor- Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • MC manifestation of RB- leukocoria
  • MC primary orbital (malignant) tumor in children- Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • MC orbital benign tumor in adults- Cavernous hemangioma
  • MC orbital benign tumor in children- Capillary hemangioma
  • MC cause of upper lid malignancy – Sebaceous cell carcinoma
  • MC orbital tumor causing proptosis- Hemangioma
  • MC primary intraocular tumor in adults- Uveal melanoma
  • MC primary intra ocular tumour in children - Retinoblastoma
  • MC intraocular tumor in adults (overall)- metastasis
  • MC cause of metastasis in Choroid in males- Lung cancer
  • MC cause of metastasis in choroid in females- breast cancer
  • MC site of Metastasis of uveal melanoma- Liver
  • MC site of BCC eyelid- Lower lid

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of torsion of the testis in adolescents?

choices.text: Seperation of the epididymis from the body of the testis
Abnormal contraction of the cremastric muscles

questions.solution:
The most common cause of torsion of the testis is the high investment of tunica vaginalis which causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell (bell­clapper abnormality). This is typically a bilateral abnormality.

For torsion to occur one of the following abnormalities must be present:

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality
  • Inversion of the testis. The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis. This allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

Testicular torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain.

Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction.

The morphologic changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction depending on the duration of torsion. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.

If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of the onset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable. Contralateral orchiopexy is performed to prevent recurrence in the unaffected testis.

Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth and the cause is unknown.

The below image shows a gross specimen of torsion testis.
